quoteFirst: At one o'clock we halted at Sar Ohha, after a journey of five hours and a half, or about eleven miles; and on the 18th, at half past six, left Sar Ohha. quoteFirst: Locke, for the sake of nonchalance, carefully selected another cigarette from his case and lighted it.  A
quoteLast: to-morrow night!  If it were not pitiable, it would be absurd that the old man should have come down here in this manner to the boathouse to make an appointment for to-morrow night, when in the natural course of events he would have been afforded an endless number of infinitely more convenient opportunities to make the same request!  And why to-morrow night, other than to-night, or this afternoon, or even now?  And why at such an hour?  It was useless to ask the question for it found its answer simply in the workings of a poor, unhinged mind--and yet Locke
title: The Four Stragglers

quoteFirst: On the other bank a small and almost vertical railroad, worked by a rope on the American side, hoisted us to the top. At half-past one we took the express, which put us down at Buffalo at a
quoteLast: . After visiting this large new town, and tasting the water of Lake Erie, we again took the New York Central Railway at six o’clock in the evening. The next day, on leaving the comfortable beds of a “sleeping car,” we found ourselves at Albany, and the Hudson Railroad, which runs along the left bank of the river, brought us to New York a few hours later.

quoteLast: , allowing fifteen minutes at Centreport, and fifteen more to land their passengers at Middleport. If the Ucayga could get off on time, she was safe enough on her connections.

quoteLast: .  Ste. Marie was depressed.  There remained almost all of the afternoon to be got through, and Heaven alone could say how much of the evening, before he could have his consultation with Richard Hartley.

quoteLast: On a distant ridge inland, a tall openwork structure commandingly situated, with a statue of the Virgin standing on it.  A devout country.  All down this river, wherever there is a crag there is a statue of the Virgin on it.  I believe I have seen a hundred of them.  And yet, in many respects, the peasantry seem to be mere pagans, and destitute of any considerable degree of civilization.
title: Following the Equator: A Journey Around the World
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910
